ygData.subject: New Picbreeder Applet Lets you Visualize and Modify Underlying CPPNs
ygData.msgSnippet: I am pleased to announce an excellent educational tool by Jeremiah T. Folsom-Kovarik that we have just added to Picbreeder: http://picbreeder.org/ All images

From: "Ken" <kstanley@...>
Subject: New Picbreeder Applet Lets you Visualize and Modify Underlying CPPNs
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=54567749; y=muPoA4usgJnb9BG_2JpWsSkq5jKCvvriLU-RlblXjmixo0g15ipR
X-Yahoo-Profile: kenstanley01

I am pleased to announce an excellent educational tool by Jeremiah T. Folso=
m-Kovarik that we have just added to Picbreeder: 

http://picbreeder.org/

=
All images on the site now include a "DNA" button (directly below each imag=
e) that launches you into the CPPN visualization applet for that image.  

=
This visualization tool is much more sophisticated than just a way to see t=
he CPPN.  In fact, it shows you the "hidden patterns" computed at each hidd=
en node of the CPPN.  That is, instead of displaying nodes as circles, it s=
hows a little picture of the pattern computed by that node.  This visualiza=
tion gives unprecedented insight into how the CPPN is building patterns pie=
ce of by through composition and combining.  Not only that, but you can als=
o change weights and do "knockout" experiments by deleting nodes in real ti=
me and watch the effects not only at the final output, but throughout the e=
ntire network of hidden images.

The experience of playing with this tool r=
eminds me of the way that biologists try to decode gene regulatory networks=
 by determining the expression patterns of genes along the body axes.  (For=
 example, Drosophila flies are a popular subject of such study.)  However, =
in Picbreeder we have the advantage of complete information, meaning that w=
hat a biologist would take years to figure out for an organism, we can lite=
rally discern in seconds for a Picbreeder image.

It is interesting to obse=
rve how images are built from primitives near the bottom of the network tha=
t later combine higher up to yield more complex shapes and gradients.  It i=
s also interesting to look within lineages and see how some hidden patterns=
 are conserved internally.  There is a whole lot to learn, and I have alrea=
dy learned a lot after only hours of playing with it.  The combination of a=
 massive evolutionary database on Picbreeder (over 7,000 images) with this =
analysis tool means you can in effect perform scientific investigations ins=
ide Picbreeder without any programming or special technical skills.

The to=
ol is intuitive, but you may be interested in all the bells and whistles, w=
hich are described in this long-form documentation: http://picbreeder.org/a=
nalysisDocumentation.pdf

Shorter instructions are displayed below the appl=
et itself when you load it.

I would like to thank JT Folsom-Kovarik for th=
e excellent contribution.

ken
